Achromobacter veterisilvae is a species of gram-negative, aerobic, non-spore-forming, and motile bacterium. It was first isolated from soil samples collected from an old-growth forest in Japan. The cells of A. veterisilvae are rod-shaped and measure approximately 0.5-0.8 μm in width and 1.2-2.0 μm in length.

Taxonomically, A. veterisilvae belongs to the genus Achromobacter, which is a member of the family Alcaligenaceae within the phylum Proteobacteria. The genus Achromobacter comprises several species that are commonly found in various environmental habitats, such as soil, water, and clinical samples.

Physiologically, A. veterisilvae is capable of growing at temperatures ranging from 15°C to 37°C, with an optimal growth temperature of 30°C. It can utilize a variety of organic compounds as carbon and energy sources, including carbohydrates, organic acids, and amino acids. The bacterium is also capable of denitrification, a process in which nitrate is reduced to nitrogen gas.

Genomic analysis of A. veterisilvae has revealed insights into its ecological adaptations and potential roles in nutrient cycling within forest ecosystems. Further research on this species may contribute to our understanding of microbial diversity and functions in natural environments.
